If the past few animes you have watched were really good, I suggest you watch this. This is the the kind of anime that you might not care to finish, but it will help you to appreciate all the better series that are out there.
The story is almost non-existant, which usually isn't a problem. I like slice-of-life. But the overall concept of Rosario was so interesting, it seems like such a waste of potential.
Art? I mean, they knew how to draw panties pretty well. And the second season's opening is rotoscoped, which is pretty cool.
The sound is nothing spectacular. Most sound effects here could befound in a soundboard somewhere.\n\n
To be fair, I did like some of the characters by the end. I really was rooting for the obvious main pairing. But overall, they cast is just a generic set for a harem anime.\n\n
Like I said, it's good enough to watch, but it will leave you with an appreciation for better anime.

This review encapsulates my review for the entire series because for some stupid reason My Anime List insists on splitting it up into two different shows. I'm not sure why.
This is by far the worst anime that has ever been made. I've lost sleep over the abysmal quality presented with Rosario + Vampire. This was the first anime I have ever seen and the entire time the weeaboo of a friend I had insisted me that it gets better. 
It doesn't get better.
The first episode establishes everything the show is going to be. Panty shots and pathetic characters. Tskune and Moka are the worst leadsa show could ever have. Weak male character leads can be a good thing with an example being Accel World. This can be good because it allows for good development of said character. However Tskune is reliable in how awful he can be. He has one redeeming action throughout the entire series and it's not even the ending of it all. I thought that after all my suffering through these 26 episodes there would be a pay off. There's not, there's no reason to finish this anime, and there's no reason to start this. \n\n
1/10 avoid entirely if you have self-respect.

This series is definitely for boys. There are boob and butt shots everywhere. The storyline become predictable rather quickly and the humorous scenes become redundant. I had a hard time making it through this series, getting bored often, if you're a dude you'll be fine but if you're a woman beware, you could get bored. Plus side, I heard the manga is better.

Just finished watching the manga, will plan to watch the anime as well.
I read the reviews and overral rating prior to watching this and i expected an "average" or so, it indeed was.
I mean it's entertaining, it's fun to kill your time, but it's not an anime that leaves a deep impression in you in any way. 
The character / plot development in the beginning was really interesting. A human boy meets a very attractive vampire girl and they fall for each other, i wanted to see more. But as the episodes rolled, it was the same old thing over and over. A new "monster"appears out of nowhere and they defeat it. The two main character's relationship doesn't improve much either. It pretty much dragged like that for the entire series and ended abruptly. Forunately, they're coming out with a season 2 which i am planning to watch.


They're both afraid of committing and telling each other their true feelings, something i hate about animes. The romance is very childish, they have a tough time admitting they like each other. Aside from the romance, every episode is just a new "monster" they have to face. There's some comedy here and there and the running gags are a bit over-used


Story

7/10

Looked like it had potential, but the anime does too much fan service. The manga toned it down but the plot just really deviates and it feels like a filler heaven. Every episode in the manga felt like a filler, it was pretty annoying. 


Art

9/10

The art is flawless, that's all i can say. The only reason i wanna watch the anime is cause of the amazing art, however there's a bit too much "fan service" as well.


Sound

8/10

Not bad.


Character

8/10

The characters were actually pretty well thought out and memorable. One thing i can stand about animes/manga's is generic looking characters that DO NOT stand out. Everyone in the series was pretty memorable, i can picture them and see their uniqueness.


Enjoyment

8/10

I gotta say i enjoyed it, but it definitely felt like a naruto filler with every episode. New random enemy appears out of nowhere and they have to take them down, repeat rinse, very dull after a while. 


Overall

8/10

It didn't suck, so in other words it's enjoyable overall. This is DEFINITELY something not "deep" like Elfen Lied or Evangelion (which gave me trouble sleeping for a week, lol). It's just something fun to watch, especially if you have a girlfriend/boyfriend with you, it always makes things much better.

Vampires, witches, werewolves and other monsters. Rosario to Vampire proves that even with them you can make your own personal harem. Effortless romantic comedy with halloween atmosphere.
Aono Tsukune arrived to a new school. We have a default beginning but something seems fishy. Since Youkai Academy is a school for… monsters. Aono as a human is imperceptible because of  an important rule of  this academy- every student must be at his human form. Normal people at monster world aren’t welcome. In some horror like atmosphere everyone would run away but Tsukune found some reasons to stay. This reason is Moka Akashiya, a pink hairedvampire. The choice to stay may be apposite because to our hero’s harem have joined another three girls . If he can stay with this four girls, the fact that he can lose his life to some monster is nothing. Besides every girl gladly protects our defenseless human. Especially Moka, who is one of the most powerful monsters, a vampire.


Rosario to Vampire is a combination of shounen, harem and ecchi genre. We can add some mahou shoujo and  horror too. The author doesn’t hide his inspiration for monsters. We have all kinds of them, from European legends and from Japanese myths. Main heroin is a vampire, later appears a werewolf , witch, succubus and other monsters. A fair group from horror story. Every of them tries to kill or seduce Tsukune. 


The episodes are very schematic. To Tsukune and his group time flows by and than they get to know one of the students. This student unveils his true monster form. It tries to attack Tsukune, so Moka come to rescue and defeats the delinquent with her roundhouse kick. This repeats for almost all episodes. Rosario to Vampire is a typical ecchi genre. The difference is that the story is set in a monster school. From this assumptions we know that it will be funny, relaxing and without any obligations and if you don’t expect anything special it is. Though the humor isn’t too good.


As a typical harem anime every heroine tries to seduce the main hero. Everyone has their own episode to show their personalities but after that they don’t develop. Most of time we have our main pair Tsukune and Moka. That’s a big loss because the female characters are likeable and interesting. Sweet witch Yukari dressed in a characteristic hat and cape, succubus Kurumu that has an ability to seduce and a snow woman Mizore a quiet stalker. A well done small harem. But they don’t have too much screen time. Instead of that we have many episodic characters that appears only in one episode. 


A big advantage of this title is the female vampire. When Moka unlocks her eponymous rosario she changes like a magical girl from cute and delicate person to a blood-thirsty invincible vampire. Plus she get some body increase for free. This second form of Moka will win  everyone hearts. She’s sexy, almighty and has a good kick. 


The animation is very accurate. We have a lot of deep colors. The female monsters have pink, violet and blue hair. The background is very colorful too. We have a genial surrounding atmosphere. Graveyards, crosses, pumpkins. Maybe they aren’t horror like but we can say that there is Halloween Day all the time in Youkai Academy. Mokas transformation is also good looking. It’s similar too magical girl transformation but we have domination of bats. Opening and ending singed by Nana Mizuki show two sites of this title- harem and monster fights. 


Manga and anime of Rosario to Vampire are different. First of all the plot in the anime don’t develop at all. We mostly have the harem site here. In the manga Tsukune became involve in various organizations and mysterious intrigues. The atmosphere is more serious and dramatic. The anime producers didn’t want to make anything beside a typical ecchi. If you want some harem in a different convention watch the anime. If you want some harem with intrigues and fights read the manga.

Overall the series was good, it had a few obvious downturns but it was nonetheless fun to watch. 
Cons
Probably the two worst things about the series are the repetitiveness and the awkward cliche's that follow in every, and i mean EVERY, 'action' scene.
All combat is exactly the same, from initiation to dialogue and the combat styles of each character. Not only that but the romance dialogue gets very cliche and repeats the same scenes many times over for no real reason.
Characters will just open up 'lovey-duvey' dialogue mid combat that can stretch for up to and over 20 seconds and completely neglect their opponants whojust sit their and wait in a painfully obvious way.\n
Pros\n
The character development wasn't bad and the art is very easy on the eyes. Theirs nothing special about the main character, hes easily relate-able to the average but is fairly unique when compared to many protagonists of similar titles.\n
The comedy in Rosario + vampire was quite entertaining and had some parts where i could have giggled like a school girl. \n
Overall the series was pretty good but is only worth watching if you have the time, its not something you should go out of your way to watch.

Let me start off this review with an overly exaggerated *sigh*. I had this series recommended to me as I am a fan of romance comedies (Love Hina, Ah! My Goddess etc.). This is not comparable to those simply because it takes fan service to an entirely excessive level and at the cost of any form of character development or legit story. I pushed through it because I liked the idea and quickly decided to read the manga version (I cannot recommend it enough!). 
**Compared to the manga** The manga became everything I was looking for and goes on for much longer than the animedepicts anyway. The manga has much less noticeable fan service, actual character development, better action and just as much if not more humor at times, definitely a worthwhile read. 


**Standalone** Be advised that the story actually differs immensely (and inaccurately) from the manga, presumably due to its sheer focus on boobs and panty shots. While that may be what some are looking for, I for one found its emphasis unbearable. 


**Rating** I gave this a 4 because I love the actual story (manga) so much that I gave it a courtesy point. The sound is repetitive, out of place and odd. The main character is a cut-out piece of board and the girls are virtual inflatable blow-up dolls for your amusement. The attempt at a story is repetitive and predictable and the only presentable aspect of it is its rather appealing animation art. Consider myself a virtual lifeguard, as I am writing this review as a raft, hoping to save as many prospective fans from the disappointment of the anime and instead guiding them safely to the manga version :)

Rosario + Vampire was one of my first ventures into a specifically ecchi-style anime. Of the few reviews I read about this series I gathered the idea that it wasn't going to be particularly amazing and while I admit it might not make my top 5 it was entertaining in its own way.
This series had some of the best animation of its genre that made every episode wonderful to look at. In addition to this the character personalities were charming to say the least (Mizore 4 life). For example, the subtle reminders that while she looks human, Kurumu confuses typical human colloquialisms only to becomically corrected by Yukari. Coupled with great music R+V was certainly worthy of an 8, but I'm afraid not much more than that.\n\n
While the characters, animation, and music were entertaining enough the story line and episodic nature was fairly weak. And honestly, that's pretty okay with me. If anything, this series made me really interested in picking up the manga right away and start reading. Even though the plot development and story construction was mild, it is pretty clear that I could gain a better appreciation for the story if I read the manga as well.

If you first watch the anime and then read the manga, you'll have a blast.  But if you first read the manga and then watch the anime (especially the second season) you'll end up extremely frustrated.  I'll get into this more in my review of the second season, but keep this in mind when reading some of the reviews.
I'm going to forgo the normal category review and get straight into the meat of this season.  The anime version of R + V is a shounen mixture of high school slice of life/harem that finishes up with a battle at the end.It mostly follows an episodic structure with some character development between the "episodes".  


Classic harem tropes are followed, and you'll recognize some of the classic female characters in this sort of anime.  Also, the lead guy, in order to not make him a complete douchebag, is largely clueless as to the level of affection of his "friends".  Not that these harem elements are a bad thing--many of the best anime have semi-harems or harems usually (Steins;gate, Code Geass, Evangelion, etc)--and when done right provides funny and interesting stories for the male lead.


The characterization is superb, the stories generally interesting, and the setting pitch perfect.  It its category, shounen/harem, it's probably one of the best if not the best.  The art, sound, and voice acting are all solid.  


So why the negative reviews?  Well, the anime suffers the same problem as what happened with the first Fullmetal Alchemist.  The anime's creators for whatever reason will sometimes depart from the source material or mix up the stories, resulting in a weaker product.  It also underestimates its audience by dialing up the fan service to overkill.  But the first season does stay closer to its source material, and thus is significantly stronger than the second season.


I would highly recommend watching the anime first and then jumping into the manga.  Think of the anime as an appetizer until you can move onto the main course.

Rosario Vampire. Not a kid anime. A very VERY mature ecchi anime. If you don't know what ecchi is, then its perverted things and NOT for little kids to see. Its a okay series, I mean, its not bad, I liked it. But its just so strange.
Story line 7/10-There is no spoilers,so its fair. Tsukune is a failed high school student. He comes across Yokai Academy. When he gets there, he mets a pink haired girl,and becomes friends with her. He then finds out that the school is for monsters, and if any humans are to be found, they'll be killed.(Tsukune is a human). Nowhe must live with monsters. The story line was a great idea. I really liked the cleverness of it. The story just felt to simple. It was a great idea, but it would have been better if the story could have explained more with more episodes. I still like it, but it could have been better.


Characters 7/10-The characters in this anime are enjoyable, but annoying. Moka is a good character. Shes funny. Tsukune is just strange. Mizore is the best character in my opinon, because shes cool(literally). Kurumu is funny, eta. The witch girl is annoying, and the monsters in this anime are just, weird. watch it, and you'll see what I mean.


Sound Track 6/10-The music is okay. The opening theme song is good. The rest of the music is also good, but it doesnt stand out, unlike other anime. There really isn't anything for me to say about the music because I never really thought of it as amazing.


Art 8/10-The best thing about this anime. The art. Its very bright,and fits the anime well. It does has some dart animation, and that doesn't fit it well, but the color is good for everything else.


Enjoyment7/10-I liked Rosario Vampire. It was funny, which is why I enjoyed it. However, its not as good as I thought it would be. I liked the art, and the comedy, and the story line, but its not the most enjoyable anime ive watched. 


Overall 7/10-There are tons of better anime out there, plenty. Rosario Vampire is good for anyone who loves mature, ecchi anime. Its enjoyable, but just strange.

It seems that most animes that fit into this genre is forced upon me by my husband....anyways, if you look at this anime as a harem/canon parody then it's hilarious, if you were actually expecting a good story...then maybe not but then again this is also a great example of how an anime becomes a downplayed version of a manga....
SO we have the main hero who is (obviously) in love with the female lead (and loves him in return) and is a innocent perv who is surrounded by girls who just dont get the clue, add in some pedo scenes here and there and BOOMRosasrio vampire...it's not soo bad, I mean I watched the second one, the only annoying thing was the witch, it turned very serious, enough to make me go "Omg, this is amazing!" but then she joins them and it goes to being all silly again...its like they tried to make it serious at some point to edge off the darkness but ended up with hello kitty riding with my little pony with large breast implants and panty shots instead.

fuhh...... the vampire gal is hot!!!!! but if u want to watch this anime, i recommend you guys to read the manga first.the story line doesn't realy differ so much but i guess in the anime, some parts of the manga was skipped. 
    overall, it's a great show.the sound efect's realy cool and wait till you see the theme song......SUPREME COOLNESS!!!!!

I watched both seasons of this show after I bought the first volume of the manga (which is better than the adaptation). While its formulated, repetitive and too predictable I still really enjoyed it.
Story: First episode you get introduced to Tskune, some average high school boy. He gets enrolled in a school strictly for monsters in another world. He meets Moka, a vampire with two personalities, the true vampire one which is locked away when the Rosario is on her chest that only Tskune can remove apparently. For a majority of the show:
- Tskune is with Moka and something happens
- One of them (and lateron their friends) meets an antagonist

- Antagonist threatens Tskune, Moka or friends

- Tskune "accidently" takes off Moka's rosario

- Vampire Moka kicks everyone into submission

- Antagonist is defeated or becomes their ally


It gets more spicy in the last 2 - 3 episodes, but that's the formula for the rest of the show.


Art: Nothing wrong with the art style from what I can see, I like it.


Sound: I watched it in English dub (first version I could find and I felt lazy), sound is good.


Characters: Tskune just seems the average cliche teenage boy in high school who suddenly gets a harem of girls who want to date him.  Moka seems like his obvious girlfriend choice, but the friends he picks up after a formulated battle want to take him too and they all fight over him. The antagonists just happen threaten Tskune and co. and then get beaten up. The narrator bat (who wasn't in the manga) is just really annoying.


Enjoyment: Much as its formulated and predictable I did enjoy it, still reading the manga which is better than its adaptation with a better story.


Overall: The adaptation just seems to have plucked some chapters out of the manga (including key chapters like the first one, the ones where he picks up his friends, the school trip, but the end is actually a really early on chapter, the chapters adapted into the anime were swapped around though). Not really a show to be taken seriously, but I wouldn't mind watching it again.

The story is all about a teenage boy who can't get into high school, but through an amusing circumstance, ended up getting into a school but not an ordinary one called Youkai Gakuen. On his first day of class, while trying to find his way to the school, he stumbled upon a very beautiful girl. They immediately became friends and the boy said that he will surely have a nice time in his new school. Little is he aware of what kind of school he is entering or the true identity of the girl.
Rosario + Vampire is presented in a 1 monster per episode format,and new characters are introduced gradually as the series moves along. Admittedly, the format tends to become a little boring for a while because in the surface the story doesn't seem to have any direction, but for people who love harem and fan-service, this is but little annoyance for enjoying the show. The series ended quite abruptly leaving much to be desired, thankfully there is a season 2 (by the time of this writing). 


As expected of GONZO, the animation is superb, the movement is very fluid, and the girls are really cute - very nice for any harem shows. The fan-service is a plus, and you can never be tired watching the transformation sequence of Moka as she transformed from a whimsy character to a total badass and powerful vampire.


The OP and ED is nice, very appropriate for the show. Background music is also superb! I especially like it when Aono and Moka look face-to-face blushing while saying each other's name and in the background it is playing the "lalalalala...lalala...lalalalala" sound, it's really cute and hilarious!


I like the anime in general. It's only 13 episodes, not much room for character development. I wish to see more development on the relationship of the main characters, but it is not something that the series focuses on in its first season. Recommended for anyone who loves romance, comedy, fantasy, harem and fan-service.

After all the hype and yearnings of this "harem with notorious amount of fanservice" series is all out of steam, time to let it all out... :P
Story: 6/10
Not much of a unique or original story as it this one picked up the usual and cheesy "school-type HAREM" feel with a monster twist in itself. It would have been a good one if added elements can be inserted to make it feel special in some ways to veteran otaku viewers thus definitely lacking in a meaningful plot.
Art: 8/10
GONZO, GONZO, GONZO. As I expected, the story may be bad in a way but the art work andstyling was done pretty much above average. In some of the end episodes, the quality improved a tad bit but noticeable.\n\n
Sound: 8/10\n
Nana Mizuki did a good part in making up for the OST of the series. OP theme is upbeat and catchy while the ED is mysterious but vibrant. BGMs throughout the series is good too with the addition of off-beat humor and hints of naughtiness.\n\n
Character: 7/10\n
Love em or hate em, there is no stopping why most people adore Moka and hate Tsukune or the other way around. Character development in some of the characters are a big ? since more questions are being thrown. Voice actors are good but some (cheesy?) dialogs can always be heard all the way till the end that may be a bit irritating and repetitive.\n\n
Enjoyment: 6/10\n
As a change of viewing habits, I was drawn in by the fanservice but the story really disappointed me. I was expecting that in the end, it may all end in a "bang" but a whimper of many unanswered questions. All that comes to mind that this anime brings is like a washing machine..."wash, rinse, dry...then repeat" XD\n\n

I could have lowered the score for this but I do think that since the anime will air a 2nd season, they can improve the plot very well as not to disappoint fans alike. If you like copious amounts of fanservice and pantsu shots, well...go for other anime series like Najica Blitz Tactics or Agent Aika for action and Negima (1st) if you want harem + comedy + fanservice galore. R+V and GONZO really did screw up for once but who knows once the 2nd season airs. Happy pantsu viewing-chuuu~ ^__^

To all my feminists peeps out there, and even to those who are not feminists...this anime has no plot, none.
It's all a series of excuses to show hot girls underwear in different poses. There's no character development and the female characters have absolutelly no personality at all.
However I have to said the lead guy was less annoying than the usual guys on this kind of anime. Also Its fun for me when the guy needs saving from the girls. So these factors made the anime not a total loss for me.

The visuals are great but the story has more holes than a swiss cheese. I've read the manga and I like it but what the heck did they do to the story? Sometimes I really hate GONZO mainly because they are not loyal to the source material. Well I think I could praise the character designs of this show because all the girls here are adorable and cute. This show is funny sometimes but usually its annoying. It's full of panty shots and every episode you will SEE panties I guarantee you. I also have to complain about the battles because its like 'monster ofthe day' battle and are usually defeated easily. 


Fine I admit that I enjoyed the comedic scenes of this anime but I don't really like how they played the plot. The manga is way better than this so I suggest that you should just read it than waste your time watching this but if you like shows like this then I think you will quite enjoy this.


It is said that there is a second season to this anime so the fans of this show will be overjoyed by the news.


For me this show is worth 1 out of 5 stars but I think I could forgive the show a bit because I admire their character designs and I even like some characters like Mizore Shiraiyuki.

I love the manga Rosario + Vampire so it's not possible for this to surpass it, however it did come close. For anyone who liked the manga, this is a good anime to watch. The characters were well developed and funny and i don't see why other reviewers have said they are sterotyped. I admit Tsukune is a bit of a wimp, but isn't that the fun of watching it? The sound and the theme is exciting and lively, and add to the overall enjoyment of it. The only things i can say i didn't like is the fact tsukune didn't use his vampire abilitiesas much as he did in the manga, but this doesn't matter for people who haven't read it. Overall Rosario + Vampire is an above average anime with lots of action and romance.

What more can I say about this anime? It has big breasted girls, monsters and blood sucking vampires! A must watch for those who prefer humorous monster shows rather than the darker ones. However it does have some down sides. There isnt much character development and the storyline can get a little repetitive sometimes. *Insert obligatory first review sentence here*
Now with that out of the way, let's get on with this. First off, let me begin by saying Rosario + Vampire is one of if not my favorite harem manga ever. Let me repeat, MANGA. This thing is not the manga, not in the slightest. The first few episodes seemed promising since they were following the manga however I always got a sinking feeling whenever the preview came on since they decided to advertise a different pair of panties for each episode. Nevertheless, I continued on and boy did I regret it.
Story 3/10 - Like I said, the firstfew episodes seem promising mainly because they actually follow the manga and are paced reasonably well. However, things begin to fall apart by the time the trip to the human world arc takes place. After this point, the story more or less takes a back seat until the final two episodes which has always been a pet peeve of mine. I am sick of romcom shows that think they don't need any plot progression until the last two episodes, I'm looking at you Girls Bravo. Anyway long story short this is not the manga's plot, it is a watered down version with only the bare essentials.


Art 7/10 - This coupled with the sound is probably the best part of this anime. The characters and backgrounds look nice and everyone is animated pretty well. I'm not going to go any further into this since I've never cared that much about this field.


Sound 6/10 - Like the art, the sound is pretty good. The OP is pretty catchy in my opinion and I honestly love the ED and really highlights what this anime should have been about, Moka kicking lots of ass and looking damn good while doing it.


Characters 5/10 - Here we go, this is where the differences with the manga really become distingushed. Let's start with our MC Tsukune, instead of manga Tsukune who is thrust into an unfamiliar environment, relies on Moka for a while until that isn't enough and gets powers of his own that he learns to control, we get just another generic MC who relies on Moka for the whole season except for the last damn episode. Speaking of Moka, part of her appeal was the whole mysteriousness of her other self and how she became that way, but the people making this anime didn't seem to care. In the anime, Moka never evolves past the beautiful, perfect nice girl with a badass alter ego, granted it takes a while before she does so in the manga. Next up is Kurumu, or Tits Mcgee. Even in the manga I never particularly enjoyed Kurumu but she does have some genuine moments in the manga. Unfortunately the most important thing she does in the anime is sing a song in a bikini..... moving on. Yukari the witch is next and I like how they portray witch in this world as between human and monster but not really belonging to either. In the manga she really stands on her own as a character during the club trip arc however even that is ruined in the anime which also includes another character Rubi who, even in the manga, I found her affection towards Tsukune unnecessary. Finally we have everyone favorite character, Mizore. Mizore is what made me want to keep watching since she is my favorite character, but alas even she couldn't save it. 


Enjoyment 5/10 - From what you can tell, I did not enjoy this anime, I can only see it as an insult to the source material. Aside from the character introduction episodes, no part of what made the manga so great is in the anime. Where is the school festival arc? Where's Hokuto and Kiria? Those guys are part of the reason I love the manga so much.


Overall 5/10 - My biggest problem with the Rosario + Vampire anime is that they took a series that started out as just another harem comedy but turned into a thrilling monster action series with harem elements and assumed that what it was in the beginning was what everyone liked about. I would've scored it lower but I just couldn't grade an adaptation of something I loved so low.



So yeah, this was my first attempt at a review. I'm sure my arguments aren't that great and I could have gone into more detail in some places, but I just wanted to throw out my 2 cents. I'm open to any discussion or counter-arguments.

Rosario to Vampire is a very generic fantasy ecchi/harem anime that rushes through every plot point too quickly and expects us to believe in the romance between the two main characters by default. The characters kind of make up for its failures, as Inner Moka steals the show over and over again. Kurumu is hot and fun to watch, while Mizore is interesting to say the least. The only main girl I didn't like that much was Yukari because she is a glorified sexualized loli for no reason and has no relevance to the story besides her one episode love interest and helping save theother witch girl. Oh, I should mention the generically weak and dense main male character who has absolutely no reason to be doing what he does, and of course the girls fawn over him because of his love of his "friends" and his passion to save them even though he cannot do anything himself. The plot itself is difficult to even find until the last 2 episodes and by then it's too late to save itself from failing. The ending was, as expected, a "happy" one, but to achieve this they form a plothole in how all the students magically changed their minds about Tsukune being human. It could have been done a lot better, but that remains to be seen in the next season.

Ending was disappointing, and the fan service was way to overwhelming. Really watching this made me appreciate the newer animes that are did much better with what they have.
This plot line was unique, and could have been incredibly entertaining if they developed the story more instead of all useless scenes, such as in EVERY SINGLE episode except the last two, maybe, they had her change into a vampire with the same exact changing scene and narration as if it was the first episode.
It got incredibly monotonous. Other than that I enjoyed alright, giving it a 7.

First of all, before I begin, the manga for this blows the anime out of the water. I'd highly recommend it.
Rosario + Vampire is really just taking the characters from the manga, murdering the story, and creating a huge fanbase. That being said, the anime wasn't... Awful. The series is about Tsukune, a human boy who gets put in a Highschool for monsters/demons, and tries to fit in without being discovered. Seems interesting, no?
Lets talk about the positives first. The animation style is really amazing. It looks really smooth, and has a cutesy, happy feel to it. It makes you want to keep looking atit.


The music is actually really good. Both intros are really good, and the background music for the fight scenes, awkward scenes, and whatnot are all really fitting and really enjoyable to listen to. 


That's it for the good, really. The plot isn't even there, it is clearly stated what's supposed to be going on (a human boy trying to fit in at a Highschool for monsters/demons) but it never progresses. It's mostly filler, every once in a while adding a new character, every one of which happens to fall in love instantly with the main protagonist for absolutely no reason. 


The execution of the anime was miserable. That aside, it is enjoyable to watch for humor's sake. It's cute, funny, happy, and it's something mindless to pass the time with. However, if you're looking for a plot on the level of Clannad or something, you're going to want to pass on this one, as it definitely isn't for everyone.



If you do end up watching this, please read the manga too. It's MUCH better, and it still retains the silly, mindless feel of the anime.



Thanks for reading! c:

First of all, I just want to say that very few animes make me want to write a review. The fact that I indeed did write one only proves that I do honestly love this anime.
-BASIC PLOT-
Now, back to the main topic. Rosario + Vampire is your average harem/shounen (I'd say it's more of a harem. There's more googly-eyed, cheesiness than action) with a weak, helpless guy being surrounded by big chested/cute girls, and is always making mistakes and being sexually harrassed by having boob hats or having his arm hugged by boobs...
-STORY- (6/10)
Aono Tsukune, an average highschool boy fails his grade and ends uphaving to retake it again next year. By sheer coincidence, his father picks up an acceptance letter to Youkai Academy. Excited as him and his parents are for his first day, he finds himself on a shady, stay-the-fuck-out mountainside just infront of a forest bordering the school. On his way there, he gets ran over with a bike by Akashiya Moka, who later reveals is a vampire...


The story did, in my opinion got boring at times -- I found myself skipping through an episode or two in order to cut to the chase. Sometimes the episode was filled with repetition that really wasn't needed, and saved me 5-10 minutes.


-ART/SOUND- (7/10)

The art (character wise) looked a bit old, or amatuerly drawn especially for an anime which came out in 2008. This is only my personal opinion. Usually, the only time I see this kind of anime is in old American-made hentai (which generally suck... hard), though at certain angles the character's designs looked nice. As for the scenery, it did look very detailed but just like the character art, it did seem a bit retro.

The sound was good, but I personally did not like some of the voice acting of the Japanese dub. For some characters, like Auno, it didn't seem to fit with his character.


-CHARACTER- (8/10)

The character's personalities are very different from one another, and when they're all put together in a group it's quite cute how all of their opinions and emotions clash together.


Tsukune - An innocent, and defenceless teenager who is very clumbsy about what he does, and has a hard time understanding people's obvious feelings (common in harem). He feels as though he is a minority at his school, and having a group of girls defend him only makes him feel worse. Though, when he is serious about something, he is determined and strong.


Moka - Moka is kind hearted vampire who is living as two different people. The pink haired, kind hearted, shy, cute Moka you generally see is a personality which was created in order to hold the second Moka using the Rosarie on her neck. The other Moka is a silver haired, mellow, intimidating, cute-in-a-scary-way personality. She is generally reffered to as "the REAL Moka" among her family -- this is revealed in Rosario + Vampire Capu 2. This Moka comes out whenever there is a battle, Tsukune is always the one to remove the rosarie (wether on accident or on purpose).


Kurumu - Kurumu is a succubus, a creature that uses their bodies and special ability called "Charm" to bend the will of the opposite sex. Though at first, she may seem like the evil type, it is later revealed that she is indeed a nice girl. Kurumu is generally the flirty type, and she seems to love suffocating Tsukune with her boob-trench.


SIDENOTE: Yukari and Kurumu often playfully argue with eachother about boob size. Yukari taunts Kurumu saying "they will get saggy when you get older, I still have a long time till I grow up!" And so starts an argument. Though in reality, Kurumu seems to love Yukari like a little sister.


Yukari - Yukari is a witch... need I explain what a witch might POSSIBLY be? In the beginning of her appearance in the anime, she seems like an arrogant brat who cares about no ones feelings, and only her own enjoyment. Later on though, she reveals her feelings and why she treats everyone poorly and eventually befriends the main characters.


-ENJOYMENT- (8/10)

I enjoyed this anime very much. It made me laugh, facepalm, and feel embarrased for a few characters at times. Though I think this anime wont be enjoyable to some if they're picky about character personality and story line.


Overall, I give this anime an 8/10.

This anime has quite a bit going for it in general, but the execution feels a bit lacking. In terms of characters, the cast overall is pretty great. The main characters interact well with each other, and there's some solid character and relationship development that all feels solid. Of note is Ruby's background, which got the most development and who had the strongest introduction arc, though afterwards she seemed to integrate into the group too fast, which feels somewhat strange in the final scene. But overall, the group feels cohesive and solid. However, most of the plot, and especially how the characters were framed felt lacking. Most ofthe anime up to the end has a simple loop of Tsukune getting in trouble, Tsukune taking off Moka's Rosario, and her defeating whoever was causing trouble. This is a loop that grows old incredibly fast. It's fine for the plots where new characters are introduced, as the focus is mostly on developing their background and such, but the others, while sometimes managing to hit a couple solid beats in character development, felt largely pointless. This combined with how the anime overall was pretty slow results in many episodes being quite tedious. Though I should note, this is something that as it approaches the end is no longer an issue, in that the last few episodes go in a different direction that gets away from the loop and works much better. However, the other issue still remains, mainly the way characters are framed. Tsukune is pretty useless. His character is decent enough, but he doesn't really do much beyond removing a Rosario. A good amount of the time, he's brainwashed, tied up, or other things that remove him from having any real involvement. Even in the end, in what seems like it would be the perfect opportunity to have him finally do something, Moka's still the one that strikes the finishing blow. Now, it's fine to not focus on the protagonist all the time and focus more on other characters, but that's not what this did. This kept the focus on Tsukune while he was useless, which makes the stories, many of which are quite decent, feel somewhat lame, and Tsukune's character seem worse than it is. Still, overall I'm going to have to say the plot is decent, with the last few episodes still being quite solid and it ending on a reasonably satisfying note.


The designs and style I really liked. The animation was quite lacking though, with some noticeably cheap shots, such as panning across characters the exact same way multiple times while they're talking. The animation during battle also needed to be a lot flashier, because while depth to the battles didn't feel completely necessary, it still felt like it needed to be cooler. The soundtrack I quite liked, sounding somewhat Burtonesque at times for lack of a better way to describe it. The OP was decent and the ED was good. There was also a lot of insert song use, though the use was only decent. The comedy was never really funny, but it it kept up a lighthearted mood pretty well. 


A really solid concept and good cast of characters but a mostly repetitive story that is not framed that well.  


7/10

The public opinion of Anime in general seems to be one of disdain. "It's all about a bunch of magical girls in school uniforms with short skirts, fighting a bunch of ridiculous enemies, with a lot of panty shots in between." would be more than less an average passerby's assessment of Anime on the whole. I am always one to speak up and correct those naysayers, informing them of the rich and diverse content that exists within the genre. But with "Rosario to Vampire", they actually hit the nail on the head.
This is a show that fits into the generic and stereotypical anime show likea glove. It's as if they used the old "Do It Yourself" Anime starter pack complete with checklist;


Does it take place in a school?

Yes- check.


Is the lead character a pretty, tomboyish, but still feminine girl or a super serious, spiky-haired boy?

Yes (half the time) to the first one, check.


Is there a supernatural or fantasy element that centers the plot?

Vampires, Witches, and other monsters from various folklore, yes. Check.


Are there fight scenes with guns, handheld weapons, or magical powers?

Lots of magic. Check.


Is there a mid-series break to make one season like two?

Yes, check.


Is there an obligatory fan service episode at a pool/hot spring/beach so all the female characters can be seen in swimwear?

2/3 of those. Yes, check.


When you have seen so many shows like this, you have to ask aloud, "They can't be serious with this, can they?" Well, the good news is- No. This show is very self-aware and uses a lot of 4th wall breaks for effective laughs here and there. It's refreshing the first few times, but if someone keeps telling the same bad jokes- even if someone admits their jokes are bad- it doesn't succeed in making them funny. The episodic formula of the show gets very repetitive very fast and the drastic overuse of fan service only adds annoyance to the monotonous nature of the show. It's a grind to get through.


While grinding through, you are given some decent art and some okay special effects which culminates in some of the most boring and short fight scenes I've ever seen. Even when the story does proceed far enough to finally raise the stakes and ability of the enemy of the week, it's still too little, too late as they only succeed in delaying the predictable and leading us towards a Season 2. This was all rather disappointing. 


Another so-so aspect of the show is it's use of music, with equally mediocre opening and closing themes to accompany a fair in-show soundtrack. It also has the occasional musical number in the show itself which sometimes features characters singing. All a reason to show off the voice actresses wide range of vocal talents, which brings me to the Sub vs. Dub battle. I liked the Japanese cast better than the English one, but there is very little required of either cast script wise and each performance has their ups and downs making me decide in favor of the Japanese cast by a hair, but if you're more comfortable with English dub, you won't experience much of a drop off in quality.


I'm probably being a bit too harsh on this show, it's not even close to terrible, but it fails to impress. With a TV-MA rating that could have been utilized to show more monstrous and violent aspects of their cast of monsters, it only succeeds in being a one-note program with a lot of chuckles, the occasional decent looking monster, boob jokes, and the transformation sequence into a fight scene for dessert. Remarkable for being totally unremarkable. Watch it for the little smile it gives you or just to fill out your MAL profile. 5/10. Check it out. Cheers!

In the end Rosario to Vampire was a really enjoyable experience.

A common critic of this series states that the story is poor but a lot of it is actually relationship content and exploration of the characters. However, I think they could have done this while placing emphasis on a moremeaningful plot. This anime also overly sexualizes a child which is in poor taste for me. \n\n
All that aside, Rosario really shines in some areas. The music fits the mood of the series perfectly and it's quite adorable when the characters have musical performances where they sing songs about their love. The romance that developed is very cute and compelling. There are multiple moments that will have you rolling over laughing as well. All in all, this anime could best be described as cute and cuddly, sprinkled with decent fanservice.

School is hard. But when you fail the entrance exam, what're you suppose to do? Nothing... especially when your dad finds a flyer for a private boarding school with no requirements. Seems like a good deal, until you find out that it's a school for Monsters who don't exactly have a fondness for humanity.
Story (5/10) - There seems to be a simple formula for this series. Guy accidently enrolls in a school for monsters and tries to hide his true identity, gets targeted for various reasons for being friends with a popular Vampire; fight ensues, and he's powerless to do anything, until he removes theseal for her powers, which only HE can do. She then proceeds to win the fight without any effort. During his survival of school, and his life in general, he befriends other Monsters, who fall in love with him. (Who would've thought?)    


Art (7/10) - The colors were bright and wonderful. You could really feel the growing chemistry between Tskune and Moka before something ruined the moment.


Sound (4/10) - The narration of what happens to Moka when her power is unsealed is nice, but wears thin. The Intro and Outro of the show isn't anything special, something to let you know how the meat of the episode was starting, or letting you know that it was over, and you can move on to the next.


Character (6/10) - Tskune is your average teenage who got thrown into a 'strange' situation, to say the least. That doesn't stop him from being who he is and positively effecting those around him, particularly the girls who've fallen for him. 


Enjoyment (6/10) - This Anime was one some recognize at first glance. Since I couldn't, I watched it, and it wasn't horrible, but felt that it could've been better.


Overall (5.6/10) - This is the lowest-rated score I've given so far, but I'm sure there's worse out there. Despite it, I'm interested in seeing what the source Manga is like.

Let me start off by saying that I have not read the manga, I plan to, but with every written piece that has been adapted into a visual performance of some sort, I try very hard to view them as separate works of art. Was the story all that great? No. The plot of most every episode is the exact same thing, just with different words. I felt the charactersgrew tremendously through the episodes and by the time I had finished watching, I had become very attached to each of them. This review contains no spoilers. It’s safe to read.
Also, this review is for both season one and season two (Capu 2).
Story: 3/10

I like the idea of youkai (monsters) going to a school. Actually, no. I LOVE the idea. 
Art: 9/10
Candy for eyes. Rich colors. Great quality. Details. In one word: beautiful!
Sound: 10/10
Nana Mizuki totally one of the best people on this planet. If you don’t enjoy the story, you’ll definitely like the music! Iespecially love “Discotheque” and “Trinity Cross”. My final score: 9/10\n\n
I recommend this anime to all the perverted people that are looking for badass sexy girls with a bit of supernatural and action but lots of ecchi, funny scenes! Be sure to watch in a good mood and FIND A UNCENSORED VERSION (seriously, it’s totally annoying when you have it censored).

With attractive character designs, on-model appearance, detailed backgrounds, and a brilliant color palette, the production quality of Rosario + Vampire is strong. A Funimation cast of regulars give a great performance for the English dub.
Rosario + Vampire is comfortably formulaic: a panty-laden harem comedy with monsters, plus a few magical girl elements (Moka’s repeated transformation scenes & catchphrase).
Tsukune is a cookie-cutter male lead: a lovable, pure-hearted wimp who only has eyes for Moka but still likes the other girls as friends. Granted, Tsukune’s flimsiness is more excusable given the monster-power of the other characters. Throughout the series, his girls protect him through climactic one-on-one fights.This pattern continues with minor character growth, leading up to a few final episodes framed with themes of friendship and tolerance. Some viewers may find this repetitive.


For humor, this show is hit or miss. Characters like to break the fourth wall, which can be fun. The music director did a terrific job of choosing themes to support the comedic moments of this series. The running gags which get further lampshade treatment by a bat character mascot (rather than the writers making new jokes) get stale very fast.


Aside from some predictable jokes and episode pacing, Rosario is good, light entertainment. There is much action, and some surprisingly emphatic scenes.  The main attraction of Rosario + Vampire  is the fanservice, and it is present in every part of the series (on a Najica Blitz Tactics level), to include the opening, closing, and “Next Episode” preview. If you enjoy ecchi anime and risqué situations, this show will appeal to you.


Manga Fan Disclaimer:


The timeline of Rosario+Vampire the anime is very different from the manga. There are many storyline changes. Some characters appear earlier, some are anime exclusive, and certain minor characters appear more. It is the general consensus among fans of the manga that this show took excessive liberties.

At first glance this may seem like your typical, big breasted, typical guy, mythical girl anime but, you have to dig deep to get to the heart of this anime. The plot is simple, a normal human boy "coincidentally" gets admitted to a school filled with monsters. This anime is considered a romance but you have to go past all the fan-service to find it. The relationship between the main character and main girl is quite funny and at times heart warming. His extreme love for her no matter who or what gets in the way is surprisinglysweet. The comedy is slap stick for its repeated boobs to the face and trips with panty shots. For all the ladies, like me, that take a chance at this anime, you have to try your best to forget about all the breasts laying around. The fan-service,to say the least, gets old fast. If you stick with this though, and don't give up, it can turn out to be somewhat funny and romantic. So I gave the story a 7, since it is quite typical and hard to find the true meaning behind the work. Though it is still high since the plot is there, somewhere.

      The art work on the characters is... once again typical. The girls are very cute and extravagantly made to look "sexy", like most ecchi animes. The boys are typical and oh so very plain. If you are a girl watching this, there are few fan-service for us ladies. A couple times throughout the main guy has his shirt off, but it is so plain and not very well drawn out that it is not very attracting. Though for the lads the girls boobs and panties are typically well drawn and bouncy , very very bouncy. You may be wondering , why such a high number for the art, well it is the landscapes. The human world, nature, and Yokai Academy is very well drawn. It has attention to detail, but not to realistic. 

      The sound on the character is well. The voice actors do a good job representing their role on the character. The guys voice is plain but sweet. All the girls are cute and each have their on role. Either the voice actor can play the seductive girl or the cute innocent one, they make it work. Why such a low number than, the music. The same repeated quotes and music played every fight, romance, or dramatic scenes get old, so so quick.

       Even though I hate so much on the characters they actually are quite unique. Their is one thing you don't see to much which is a stalker. The typical moe girl, the normal sweet girl(and her sadistic side), and many others. With each introduction into a new character, the producers give enough time to get to know them. They each have very deep personal stories and sides, except of course the main guy. Anyway, each character is still very well represented the way they were supposed to be.

       Enjoyment, this really just matters on the viewers eyes. If you are a guy then this will be more like porn then anything. The girls though may get to see the true meaning and enjoyment in this anime. Except of course if you are a decent enough guy to see past it too.

       Overall it is a pretty typical anime, but still has enough RomCom, mythical creature, action fights to keep you through at least the first season. The second season, I believe, is a lot better so if you can fight through this one, and another round of fan-service, you may be able to see what Rosairo Vampire is all about.

Get ready guys for a lot of nose bleeds. Get ready girls for a lot of feels.

                          Love, oreo23a

What do you get when you take a vampire monster show and make a love story about it? You get something that is exactly like Twilight. At least, close to it in a sense but with more sexual stuff it seems. I am not going to lie, this show is extremely ecchi with its use of panty shots. Those who are like me might wonder just what this show has besides that and I actually wonder that myself. From the personalities to the ecchi, it just seems like another school life show.
We start out with a character named Tsukune Aono who is pretty much aaverage human… actually should I consider him below average since he flunked most of his high school entrance exams? Anyway, his parents seem to be the type of people to be so air headed that when they find an entrance letter to a school, they just take it and have their son go to a school they know nothing about in typical anime trope. To this point, I wonder if most anime characters would actually be better off if they were considered orphaned or their parents are abroad because most parents who stay with their children seem like complete idiots. Going back to Tsukune, there really isn’t anything at all that makes him stand out. He has average looks, a slightly below average grade point average (I’m guessing because of the tests), and is from a middle class family. He has average temperament, and overall is a bland character. So why the hell does all these magical creatures want to get with him? The only thing that explains it is that Moka seems to like his blood a lot. That’s really all there is about it. It’s like if Edward told Bella he liked her for her personality. (For real, I do not like Twilight. Bella just seems to have no personality at all.)


Next, we have the Vampire Moka… who does not act like a vampire for most of the series. Sometimes I wonder if her pink hair dye seeped into her brain and permanently damaged it as she is a pretty big air head. First glance of her we see is her panties by the way. She is not winning best intro scene for the main character award as we don’t get to see her face first, it’s her butt. In fact, most scenes with her, I wonder if she is a talking butt or boobs as they keep on centering in on those areas. I don’t understand why a school would even say it’s ok to have a school uniform that does not cover the girl’s butts at all because no matter what, we get a nice long look at those panties even from a distance. For the longest time, I have been wondering weather I should call this a magical girl anime as well because there is a lot of transformation scenes because of Moka’s other side. I would rather that this other side be the main character of this show as she seems to be more put together… more sex appeal which the artists would probably play off of but at least the personality would be better. 


Another woman that seems to be all over Tsukune is Boobie McFlirty… I mean Kurumu Kurono. Sorry but throughout the whole show, I only really understood her as the Succubus because that was all her character really was. She throws her boobs around so much and her shameless panty showing. She ended up being a love rival to Moka but I really didn’t even understand why it happened. Her first reason is to help make sure that succubi don’t die out… and then because he just decided not to let her have her wings and tail from being ripped off.


Then we have miss pedophile bait… I mean Yukari Sendou. By now, I think you can tell that I never really remembered any of the characters names. They were just stereotypes that I could not get away from. I could never understand her much as she seems like a cute lesbian girl who is a child prodigy, meaning that she is a young girl who skipped a few grades. If you want an example of this, look at Chi from Azumanga Daioh or Negi from Negima. Unlike the two I listed off, Yukari is just childish and immature. I never have seen one time in which she acted more adult or smart. Now the lesbian part is because she falls head over heals for Moka, and then just like that it seems she ends up falling for Tsukune as well. I think it would have just been better if they just had her interested in Moka if they even had to make her interested in someone. By the way, get used to seeing her underwear too because boy do they not care how old the girl is. 


There are a couple other girls that end up wanting Tsukune but I can’t go fully into them as it may spoil a lot of the show. All I can bring up is that yes, there are a lot more panty and boob shots.


There is something interesting they did when it came to the fights. They actually timed the fights and tell you just how long it was through this strange narrating talking bat. I liked this for the fact that it actually added a bit to the comedy of the fights and the fact they were even having a fight happen to begin with, what I didn’t like was that it just meant that with that short of a fight, the rest of the episode was going to probably be more panties and boobs from the ‘main character’ group. Not that the fights were without panty shots and boob shots, but at least they had a little more of a reason seeing as when Moka grew into her true vampire form, her clothing didn’t grow with her. That meant that her rather short skirt got shorter and her shirt got tighter around her bust area. That was the only part that actually made any sense in having that much to see. 


The artwork is panties… panties… panties and more panties… and a little bit of boob. Alright, so besides that, the artwork is pretty average when you get right down to it. Most all of the girls are moe and the guys are sometimes bishonen to ugly, I think probably because of the fact this is such a harem style anime. When Moka does her transformation thing, they just reuse the scene over and over with the bats and its one of the reasons why I have a hard time not calling this a magical girl show. I think they also reuse a scene where Moka and Tsukune are staring at each other and calling out each others name too much as well. They will go back and forward a few times saying their names in a really glittery pink looking background and then finally the gag will hit. And since the animation was created by Gonzo, they have all the normal problems that go with that. Gonzo has had times where the animation is really nice and beautiful and then in things like action scenes or comedy scenes, things can get strange. Characters lose proportion a lot; the animation can look sort of half done, and so on.


The music of the show is nothing special. I could probably pick out only one song from all the songs they played that could be linked to this show. The others were pretty much stock music from other anime high school romantic comedies I think. The ending song is a bit energetic and mysterious piece but not really catchy. When we get to the voices, this is where the show shines… with bland to bad voices. I understand that it’s not because the voice actors are bad at all, in fact, they fit the characters really well. We have Todd Haberkorn as Tsukune (he seems to always be in the supernatural animes, doesn’t he?), Monica Rial as Yukari, and Alexis Tipton as Moka. The problem lies within the script. The script seems a bit dull compared to what the story could be. They created the show to be more like a slice of life school genre anime with a ‘monster of the day’ problem happening. Because of the over saturation of the school life genre, it feels like they tried to copy every other show out there. Oh, and why do we need a voice over explaining what happens when Moka transforms every single time? I don’t get it. Nothing changes in why she would transform so there is no need to bring it up every time.


While the show isn’t all that bad, it did bother me that they kept on showing the girls panties so much. They over sexualized the show and the characters. The rest of the show was more like typical school life drama with a guy who has so many girls flaunting around him.

Rosario Vampire is an outstanding anime, considering its unique plot. Though Rosario Vampire offers a predictable story structure with the enactment of tskunae constantly removing Moka's cross and the weekly monster that appear and the weekly introduction of new characters that join the primary protagonist.
The art and drawing of Rosario Vampire is done with effort, even myself have difficulties drawing it; The animation of the characters features incredible detail. The architecture is almost as real as life. The school looks westernized, only to show how much japan adopted western culture without compromising the integrity of its own. 
The sound effects are not so remarkable, withthe repetitive kapuchu and the eye-to-eye glances of moka and tskunae but the music, on the other hand, is well fitted for its purpose and it is a dynamic and groovy that makes sure that viewers would memorize its intro and ending music.\n\n
The Characters inside Rosario Vampire is good, involving monsters and abilities that comparable or based on traditional Japanese mythology, that gives its western viewers not just the personality of the characters but also an insight on how Japanese gives commendable preservation and blending of its culture.Moreover, the story features petty squabbles in order to get tsukunae though, the result is obviously turning to Moka, whom with her pleasing personality and subtle voice, makes tskunae fall in love for him\n\n
Overall, Rosario is an outstanding story, revolving its plot around the characters, their personalities,and abilities.

So, don't get discouraged if you're seeing 100% harem the first few episodes (who said that was so horrible, right?). It really struck a chord in me because if you look pass the superficial level of, "Oh, it's just an anime," and reallyfocus on the adversity and tension that our hero faces each day, it really tells you something about the creators' underlying message.

Would've been better if they hadn't introduced a VERY key part of the story until the last few episodes. You'll see.


Art: 8

Wow. Really stunning visuals. The only thing that kept it from being perfect is there is a considerable drop off between the animation in the first episode, compared to the last. Trust me. Watch the series, then compare the first and thirteenth. 


Sound: 8

Then they drop a bombshell by explaining that Tsukune might be in love with Mako's vampire form, instead of Mako. That just doesn't make sense if you've watched the series through.

Rosario Vampire is basically your average fantasy harem comedy that made me have mixed feelings in regards to several departments of the show.
Story: 6/10
The story revolves around a human teen who is enrolled into a school during the summer, only to find out it's filled with monsters. The show basically revolves around him and the girls he becomes friends with and their attempts to stop a random bad guy/girl from doing something bad. It also revolves around every girl in his group trying to get him to fall in love with them.
Art: 7/10
The art was good for an anime that was released in 2008, themovements looked fluid, although I had two complaints about the art. One, for starters, was the massive amount of panty shots in this series. In all the animes I have seen, I've seen a fair amount of fanservice in the form of breasts and practically nudity, but rarely panty shots. This one took it to another level, showing a panty shot in every other camera shot. Another issue I had was in one of the episodes (Epi. 9) where in animators used a shot of Kurumu, Yukari, and Mizore in the water, and then when they were talking to Tsukune and Moka, they used the exact same shot, but at a distance. \n\n
Sound: 8/10\n
The OP was good, but the ED was really great. Sincerely, the ED was the only thing I genuinely enjoyed out of every episode. The music throughout the episode is okay, but nothing noteworthy of remembering. \n\n
Character: 6/10\n
The characters in this show are okay, with Tsukune being the Main Male Character who's pretty much trying to cover his ass from being found out he's a human while being pretty much a wimp; Moka is a vampire who's very kind and caring but tries to protect Tsukune at all costs, Yukari is basically an 11 y.o. witch who has a "little sister" personality, and Mizore is an ice fairy who constantly stalks Tsukune. The only good character of this group is Inner Moka, which is summoned when Tsukune takes off her rosary, which brings out Inner Moka and she basically becomes a badass kicking the enemy's ass in a matter of seconds to minutes. \n\n
Enjoyment: 6/10\n
The anime was okay, there were scenes that made me laugh, some made me cringe from how cheesy it was or cringe when there was a scene with too much fanservice. The one thing from the show I enjoyed was, as I mentioned, the ED of the show and the fight scenes of Inner Moka and whoever the antagonist is for the episode. \n\n
Overall: 6/10\n
Rosario Vampire felt kind of a waste of time for me, it had it's ups and downs, there were scenes I enjoyed while some scenes I cringed at. If you're a fan of harems and fanservice, go ahead and watch it, if not, just move on for something better.

SPOILER FREE!!
I put Rosario Vampire on my list of anime that are simply so terrible that you can't stop watching them. A simple, average, puny, wimpy boy, played by Shinji Ikari, surrounded by gorgeous teen and preteen girls who all for some reason or another desperately want him in the pants. This theme has been done before and done to death, and the overabundance of panty shots just further pigeonholes this anime into the mediocre ecchi territory. Personally, the manga is much better and if you are reading this you should give it a try.
Story: (5/10)
There really isn't any story besides the first episode andthe last couple episodes. A human goes to a monster school by mistake and gets lots of female friends that all want his D. Every other episode besides 1, 12 and 13 are all filler and all have the same exact tone to them and the same things happen in each one.  In short, it’s your typical harem anime where the main lead is weak and needs help CONSTANTLY!


Art/Animation : (8/10)

Shueisha did a good job at animating the characters and monsters involved. There was a lot of imagination involved in the show and although not spectacular it did a good job in portraying the characters emotions and scenery.


Characters : (6/10)

The main guy is called Tsukune, and he is your typical male ecchi/harem lead, nothing to comment on further.

The main girl is Moka, who is a vampire, but unlike you would expect from a vampire she is very kind and cheerful (she reminds me a bit of Lala). She becomes Tsukune's first friend, loves sucking his human blood and falls in love with him. The only interesting and unique part about Moka is her rosario; if removed from her chest Moka becomes her true self (a true vampire); her personality changes and she becomes much more powerful.

Furthermore, 3 more girls join Tsukune's harem. The first one being Kurumu, a huge boobed succubus who tries to win him for herself. The second girl is the child witch Yukari who tries to behave like the older girls. The third girl is Mizore, a yukki-onna, and stalker.

Further characters include Gin, a guy who likes to take pictures of girls in their underwear, a teacher with cat ears and tail, Ruby another witch, Kokoa, Moka's younger sister, a bat who serves as narrator and many other minor characters.

Overall, the characters lack personality but who cares, there are some cute girls.


Sound : (8/10)

The art and the animation is nice. The OP and ED is good, nothing bad about it.


Enjoyment : (6/10)

I purely rated the enjoyment factor just on the fanservice/the cheesy romantic parts. I did not enjoy the story nor did I enjoy a weak male lead whose progression got no where. It’s a fun anime to watch, but don’t expect any real progress story wise.


Overall : (6/10)

Overall, this was not one of my favorites...it would probably be in my bottom five. But it is funny and a cute and perky romance/comedy anime. So if you like those kinds of light shows, then go ahead and watch it, you might like it. :)

MC is the only human in a monster school (like OMG what are the odds) and the story follows him trying his best to fly under the radar even though all he does is attract attention to himself. 
Characters: Awful. God awful. No. No. No. No.No. The fact that I endured two seasons of this is amazing. There is no development. This show is so cliche it is shitty. Every time the rosary comes off, Moka's alter ego comes out and some fight scene happens. Every episode this happens. EVERY EPISODE THIS HAPPENS. And of course during every fight scene, Tsukune's harem looses their clothes. \n\n
Overall: Unless you're into cliche harems that attempt to be funny but fail, don't bother. Just watch Highschool DXD and you'll be better off with that.

First thing first, THIS SERIES IS AWESOME, AWESOME I say. At first glance you will only see it as an vampire anime with no plot or whatsoever, but you are WRONG, the more the series continues, the greater it gets. Each character has his or her own unique personality and past, the art is pretty good. The story has love, action, comedy, friendship, etc. in it. Overall it's great, I recommend it. Well that's only what I think, it's up to you to decide.

I have heard that the anime is not as good as the manga, but as a person who has not read the manga, I quite enjoyed the series. The art is great and the voice actors did their jobs very well in both English and Japanese. Although harem is not exactly my style, the "love" scenes between all of the characters are quite enjoyable.
The characters definitely all have their own personalities and it is intriguing to see all sorts of monsters meeting other monsters. I find the concept interesting, but think they could have made the series even MORE interesting.
Overall, I gave the series an8 and look forward to seeing what happens to Tsukune and everyone else in Capu2!

Well, it seems like almost every comedy anime out there wants to be the new, "Tenchi Muyo", and this series is no exception.
Now I'm not saying that that is a bad thing mind you. The story is a little unique in it's own right, but there are many similarities to other shows out there. For example:
Many girls, one guy = Tenchi Muyo
Two personalities dependent on a specific item = Yu-Gi-Oh!
Girls always save guy = Ah! Megami-sama!
Many situations from misunderstandings = Three's Company
Ok, now that I have that out of my system...This series is actually rather well done. The main characters are easy to get usedto, yet don't seem generic. Character growth is a little slow, but it does exist. And while the show has a heck of a lot of, "fan service", the story is still the most intriguing part of the show.\n\n
Now I have yet to read the manga of this, so I do not  know how it will compare, but I do know that if you take the show as a completely different experience, instead of trying to make it hold up to the book (like most people do),  more than likely you will enjoy it...Especially if your a guy (don't deny it, you all know that you like fan service shots).

Well I've never read the manga, and at first look this series just seemed like another harem story. Of course not to judge a book by its cover and delved deeper.
The series gets a straight 7 across the board. It wasn't perfect and it certainly had it's down sides but the artwork was decent, similar to what is normally seen in anime and has plenty of fan service.
The music was fitting to the series, very lovey dovey in the beginning sequence then turns to a sensual feel for the ending.The story is somewhat unique but barely since the series does deal with the traditional monsterslike vampires, werewolves, and witches; along with some not so known monsters, and a human manages to trick them all- yeah! But watching the series, I see there is an obvious lack of common sense among the characters and their decisions and a constant back and forth love talk between the main two protagonist (Tsukune and Moka) and the butting in of the other girls of this put together harem.\n
While most of the characters have their own special personalities and traits they all seem to have one thing on their minds and that's the man of the series (and in some cases their is a bit of yuri). \n
Overall the anime did keep me interested and laughing, if anything it is good for embarrassing comedy and one anime you might want to be careful of watching with certain groups. \n
Also some fourth walls are broken but that just adds to the fun.
